newsitem.title: BELGIUM: No EU plan for EMU delay - EU source.
newsitem.headline: No EU plan for EMU delay - EU source.

text.p: A senior European Union monetary source said on Monday that speculation of a delay to economic and monetary union (EMU) stemmed from incessant cravings of financial markets and not any formal plans within the EU.
"There are rumours (of delay) but these are not compatible with responsible action," the official told Reuters.
"There is no plan and there isn't any discussion under the table either of who will be a member (of EMU) and who won't," he added.
Germany's record unemployment rate in January has given rise to expectations that Bonn will have difficulty in meeting the Maastricht treaty's targets on deficits and debt.

Moreover, recent reports of a compromise plan to exclude southern European countries such as Italy from the first wave of EMU participants, and German Chancellor Helmut Kohl's uncertain political future, have added to the speculative fervour.
The official stressed that it was typical for financial markets to want early answers on which countries would participate in monetary union, scheduled to start in 1999.
But such a decision, due in the early part of 1998, could not be based on economic forecasts, but on actual figures for 1997, he added.
